text: and thanks all of you for coming it's really great to be here and to share the work that my group is doing with all of
you so the topic that our lab is very interested in is computational design
for compliant dynamical robots and to get us into
this topic i thought i would start with you know the idea behind computational design right so
the idea behind our group is we're trying to make robot design more accessible to the general public we're
trying to think about how we can get anybody to be able to design a custom robot that they want so let's say this
is you and you have an idea for a robot that you want to create maybe you have some idea of some general
morphology or you know what task you wanted to do well in the future we imagine that there will be systems
that will be able to help you to create that design right even if you're not an engineer it'll be able to ask you for
specifications help you make design decisions and then very quickly take that idea and turn it into a real
physical robot that you can bring home with you and and use for your particular task right
so when we're thinking about this sort of problem how do we set it up well
first of all you know we have to be able to describe what is an actual what is a robot right and so the way we think
about a robot is well it has links and joints this is a
description that you all are probably very familiar with right because this is a description people use in urdf files
for robot descriptions so the links are include geometry inertia
you know other properties corresponding to the robot's physical
parts that take up volume right and then the joints describe degrees of freedom ranges of motion control etc right and
so the robot and well we're thinking about it is a graph that contains these parts right
in addition if we're trying to make custom robots for different types of tasks we need to think about what is a
task right and so in this case here your task is a combination of an environment which you want your robot to
be living in and some sort of objective for what you want your robot to do right and so
um if we have this sort of specification then robot design you can write down using
this very simple problem formulation right so we want to maximize our objective f over the space of possible
robots subject to physics right and so this is how we have tried to more formally think
about the problem of robot design of course i've hidden a lot of details in this
description right but i mean for different types of robot descriptions or different types of task
descriptions you can get different types of designs or different types of algorithms that allow you to solve this
problem so when i was doing my phd at mit we thought about well what if we want a
robot that's going to walk forward in a flat ground and the robot is just a
kinematic chain right made of rigid bodies and rotational joints
right so in that case what we can do is we can build these systems that allow
you to compose different types of robot geometries with different types of kinematics
and to simulate how they are able to locomote forward in a flat on a flat plane
and if all of the you know geometries are resolved inside
of the software the software make sure that the controller makes sense that all that the robot can be
fabricated then we can take this design and we can convert it into a fabrication plan which
then you can follow and have a robot walking around in front of you in about 30 minutes right so these are the sorts
of designs that we know we can create with a little bit of help from a human
in this case who is interacting with our software we're of course not the only people who have done this there's a lot of uh
approaches that people take towards this problem so what you're seeing on the bottom left here is another system and
that was developed by stelian koroz's group back when he was at cmu and they were interested in well how do we also
incorporate the electromechanical components the sensors the motors and make sure that they have a place on the
robot body what you're seeing in the middle is um additional work where
encore meadow was thinking about well how do we also take into account the rigidity of the parts that need to be created and how the fabrication
strategy affects how rigid those parts are and so
different systems over time have been trying to solve this problem of
computational robot design and have come up with different solutions for different aspects of the problem
so we've gotten a lot of functionality out of these different systems but one thing that i'd want to note is
that if we go back in time a little more unfortunately the way that we solve these problems and the ways that we
think about these problems compared to approaches that showed up around 20 years ago are not really fundamentally different
in that back in 2000 there was also this idea of well let's describe a robot
as a as a graph made of rigid components and joints and the joints of a controller
and the task is to move forward on flat ground and we can evolve this robot and we can also fabricate it right and so
these approaches that we've been using in order to make more interesting robotic structures
they allow us to think about different types of tasks but fundamentally the representations that
we're using for the robot and for the task have not changed at the same time when i show these
videos to people they always look to me and they say well those robots look like toys they're not
actually going to do anything right and so these assumptions that we've made in order to build these sorts of systems
give us designs that move they can move forward on flat planes
right sometimes they can move forward on more complicated environments but the resulting physical designs that you
see often are not really going to work on a real test that any of you might be using your
robots on right and so when i started at penn i
when i thought i started thinking about this problem and i said well we really want to make sure that the robots that we're creating these systems were
actually useful and so let's compare the robot that came out of my system
to something else that somebody else built right and so here i took a video from you know steve
collins group you can see here an example of this system which is allowing someone to
actually walk over like irregular ground right and so this is a system that some engineer has actually built right
and if you really wanted to look at the very high level the task that it is trying to solve is the same as the one on the left
right but there's a fundamental difference in that in the in the way that these systems are designed
and so one of the observations we made was really in the compliance of the system
right and the fact that the task on the right is dynamic right it's dynamical
and the task on the left is really not and so recently my group has started to think
about this problem where the major insight is well if we want our robots to be actually useful
then the ability to manipulate energy is key and of course
this is not a particularly new insight right people have known for years that there's the slip model for walking
and so if you want to be able to model how biological systems work or how energy efficient robots might walk then
you can model it as some sort of spring-loaded inverted pendulum system and the way that
we design these systems is really about energy transfer right how we think about
how potential energy and kinetic energy uh change our exchange and so
this is really the inspiration behind a lot of the work that my group has started to do recently where we're still
very interested in this idea of computational robot design and we want to think about how do we make robots for
custom tasks but we've started to integrate ideas of compliance and energy efficiency so
we've done a lot of work now in compliant mechanisms how we can create different structures with
uh programmable compliance properties um we've also thought about reconfigurable structures in the sense
of well if i have a robot that i've then tuned for a particular task
are there ways that i can manipulate that same design in order to get it to also perform other tasks
and a lot of the work that we've done is also origami inspired in that these
designs that we've created can be fabricated using folding
which we think there's a lot of value in because it allows us to directly embed electronics and actuators directly into
a sheet that then we turn into a 3d robotic object
but combining all of these ideas together then the main problem that we've been thinking about is
can we computationally think about how we can then use compliance
in order to enhance the capabilities of a robot design so
i'm not going to have time to talk about all of these projects today i was going to focus in on a couple but i'm happy to talk about
other things as well if you all have questions about them so
thinking about the problem of computational robot design and compliance um then one of the
first places that we went to was topology optimization
some of you may know that you know topology optimization is
a pretty um has been pretty successful in designing structures
um when we want to think about well how what is the mechanical response of that structure so
in um we want to build a bridge for example or if we want to
basically think about how a 3d object is going to respond to forces applied to different areas we can start with a
block of material and we can model the physics of that of that block
and we can change the density of certain areas of that block in order to manipulate the the response right and so
topology optimization is a is an approach that um people have used to try to solve the
problem of given a block of material what is the particular uh distribution of densities that i want in
order to produce a particular response and what you're seeing here is an example of that type of formulation
so here what we have is some type of objective right some type of
force or energy that we're trying to achieve we have the material density on the left
this is the object that we're going to be building and we have some physical model for how
the material deformations change as a function of the input forces right and so
in addition you sometimes have some sort of some fabrication constraints right and so these sorts of approaches like i
said give you um interesting complex structures
that produce some sort of mechanical response to given inputs right so in
this case what these authors were producing was this bridge where there's
a point load in the middle and they were trying to minimize the compliance of that bridge what you're seeing on the
right is if there were radial forces then by solving this optimization problem you
get a wheel right and so these approaches have often been applied to static scenarios
so we wanted to know well if now we want to take these ideas and then do
computational design for a robot can we take some of the same approach right and this form of this this problem
you're seeing is very similar to the form that i showed you on the first slide right so
one of the areas where we wanted to apply this was
we were saying what is an interesting complex and dynamical task that we might want a robot to achieve and
my student was very inspired by the idea of hybrid aerial vehicles these are
vehicles that have two different modes of flight right you have this multicopter based mode which is supposed
to be highly agile you can have vertical takeoff and landing and also a fixed-wing flight mode which
is highly energy efficient for long distance flight and at the same time we saw this video
out of mueller's group which is this reconfigurable quadrotor that can morph in order to get through
small spaces and we said well what if i want to take this idea of
passive reconfiguration and use it to design some sort of hybrid aerial vehicle that can switch modes
and what if because this is a very complex task what if maybe we try to solve it using
topology optimization and so the idea behind this project was as
jessica weekley is the student who was leading this project and we it
was a collaboration with chen fan fujian's group who he's at ucla and specializes in
simulations for deformable bodies so the idea here
was that we would take this quadrotor right and we would put in compliant uh
structures and we would attach a wing deployment mechanism to this compliant structure
so that when the vehicle accelerated then this comply mechanism would switch and
the wings would fold in or out and we would able we would be able to get this vehicle that switch modes passively
by using just the actuators that are on the robot itself so in this case what you're seeing is a
video for when imaginary rotors that are at where those
orange arrows are pointing apply burst of thrust
and the mass in the middle right here accelerates or decelerates
in order to switch the mechanism back and forth so this problem here we thought well this
mechanism in the middle ideal ideal application of topology
optimization but we're going to be applying it to this really interesting dynamical task and so we formulated the problem it
looks a little bit more complicated but the form is exactly the same as what i showed you before we have reaction
forces that we're trying to optimize we have um some fabrication constraints
we have actuation constraints and using that we started with this material block which
then we basically optimized using gradient descent and chianfeng fujian's
deformable body simulation and we ended up with a beam that looked like this
which produces sorry a mechanical response
that looks like this and so the idea here is that through this optimization
now we were able to achieve this by stable mechanism where each of these beams is attached to
the frame of the quadrotor and we have a big mass in the middle right so changing the location of this mass
results in reaction forces from these beams that look like this curve and so if the vehicle accelerates and
this and this platform is pushed past a certain point right this is zero right here
then the vehicle will automatically switch modes right and we said this is really great
we didn't actually have to do any of the manual design ourselves can we get this robot to actually work
in real life now and so we printed out these beams and we attached it to a quadrotor um
how did it accelerate and what you're seeing now is a comparison of the physical vehicle with the simulated one
on the left so this vehicle over here is going to accelerate and now it's decelerating the mass in the middle
continues its motion because it's the actuators aren't directly attached to it
and as a result the vehicle switches modes right so we were really excited by this result
because we think it's the first time that topology optimization has actually been applied to a dynamical task as
opposed to just a static one like the ones i was showing at the beginning and so jessica took this i took this vehicle
and she attached wings to it the wings are fake they're just there for visualization but we um put the quadrat in the air and
we said well will it actually be able to uh to switch in the air so here's the video
the vehicle turns right and then it accelerates and decelerates and what you're seeing now is that because
this mechanism switches in the middle then the wings deploy i'll play that for you again
and if we track this vehicle in the motion capture system then what you're seeing here in the
yellow dots are uh the relative location of the center platform compared to the frame of the
quadrator and you can see that there's a very clear transition between
when the platform is down relative to this frame that is the wings are folded in and when the platform is up
so we were really excited about this because we said well okay we got
we we used topology optimization to automatically design these compliant uh arms which allowed us
to get basically uh passive switching between modes for this hybrid area of
aerial vehicle and we didn't have to add any additional actuators other than those that were already on the vehicle
right all of this transition was achieved just through acceleration of um
just through the control yes i have one question about how you frame the optimization or more like how you

yeah the question was about how we formulated the optimization problem and specifically about how i said we use

we were using fanfu's simulation it's a multi-point material
method simulation which is differentiable so um yeah so all of the gradients were
calculus calculated any other questions
okay great so
like i said this we were really excited by this result um but you'll also notice
that i paused the video at a very convenient location so if i continue to play the video what
you'll see is that the vehicle flips over right part of this is because the wings are
like i said fake they're just there for visualization so you can see them deploy but another reason for this is because
of the dynamics of the vehicle so if i play back this video again it should be clearer what's going on
and actually this video over here is probably clear the assumption that we were making when
we designed the controller was that the vehicle was symmetric right but it's very clearly not and that
there's tilting in the platform because of gravity right and so
um as a result when the vehicle switches states then there's a huge counter
torque that gets induced that causes the vehicle to go out of control right
and so this was um this mean
basically what happened was that when we formulated the problem we weren't thinking about this right we made assumptions about the symmetry we
neglected to take into account some other effects of the vehicle right and so
we're currently trying to figure out well can we incorporate those sorts of
design criteria into our optimization problem but at the same time it started getting really complicated
and we said well are there other approaches that we can take to try to approach these sorts of dynamical
dynamical systems from a computational approach so those of you who
are interested in computational design have probably seen this pair of papers that came out
in the in the 1990s where people have started have been thinking about these sorts of problems
and there's a really interesting um comment from daniel whitney where he said
mechanical design cannot be like vlsi design because of interdependency
between the parts kind of like what you just saw with the hiv they lsi design
and programming compilers are very modular right in that if you design a particular subcomponent and you put it
into the rest of your design it will work the same way every time right and
it the behavior of that component doesn't depend on whatever else it's connected to
but that isn't really the same when it comes to mechanical structures right so if i
attach my compliant beam to this frame on the quadrotor and there's something else in the system that's causing a
different mass distribution the vehicle's behavior is going to be different right and so his claim in this paper is
that well compilers for mechanical designs just aren't going to work
right after that there was another paper there was a response from eric anderson who said well you know that's kind of
true but instead of just saying this problem is impossible maybe what we should be
thinking about is well when can we take a modular approach right there are some cases where you can design parts of your
system and approximate all of the other stuff
so that you can you don't have to take all the interdependencies into account and what we should be thinking about
instead of just throwing up our hand and saying it's not going to work is well when is it possible to take that
approach so this is kind of the other approach that we've been taking in my research lab is
well we try we're trying on one hand to really optimize the entire system and we're continuing to work on the hiv now
but on the other hand we're also trying to think about well can we modularize the design and can we
think about individual compliant mechanisms that then we can combine to create this more interesting dynamical
behaviors and when is that possible to do without trying to optimize the whole thing
so um before i continue are there any questions
okay so the idea then the the other approach that we've been thinking about in the
lab is this this idea of design composition right where i have a library of parts that
maybe my lab has designed or maybe you've designed or somebody else has designed and we know that it works for a particular purpose
and we can drop it into a library and these library this library of parts has
some high level representation of what each of the parts does right and now if i want to create a new design
then i can identify each of the parts in my new design with something that's in the database and i can combine them
together and because each of the parts in the database is also fabricatable then the
new design can also be fabricated right and so this sort of modular idea is the idea
that is taken in programming and in vlsi and it's the sort of idea that we're hoping you can take in certain
mechanical design scenarios and so one of the places then that we've been
starting to focus is well we have these modules that we want to combine together
some of your robot components are going to be rigid bodies which we know how to create but some of them are going to be compliant bodies because as i said
before we need to have compliance in order to to manipulate the energy of the robot right and so
we've been trying to design uh robot parts with programmable compliance
and one of our inspirations here has been the bellows theorem the bellows theorem is this resulting computational
geometry which says that if you have a structure and
you want to change its volume you cannot do that if the faces remain
rigid right so the picture you can have in your mind is like a cardboard box right so if you have all of the faces on your
cardboard box and it's and they're fixed that cardboard box is rigid right it's
not going to collapse unless somehow you deform the walls of that box right
so what that means is that if we have a structure and we want to change its volume inherently
those faces need to deform right and that deformation means that the structure is is uh storing strain energy
right which means that it has some sort of compliance or some sort of stiffness associated with it
and further that the stiffness of the structure is related to you know
how much of the face is deformed which we can compute geometrically right so what you're seeing here is an example
of a bellow structure that we've that we've been investigating it looks like this right it's a bellow
it's it has this accordion fold pattern which is typical of yellow structures and up on the right you're seeing
my student compressing the structure it's made out of thin uh poster board but it can it is quite stiff
and the reason it can be this stiff is because the faces need to deform in order for that compression to happen right
not only that but the geometry and the amount that the faces deform are going to depend on the particular geometrical
parameters of this structure and so if we change for example this this alpha angle which is in the fold
pattern that's corresponding to this 3d shape by even just one degree
we get a huge change in the mechanical response
and so what is really nice now is that we can design
the behavior of these structures purely by changing their geometry right
so based on these ideas now we can basically come up with modules that are also parameterized by geometry but they
result in different mechan different compliance right and so what you're seeing here are some experiments
um that the students did to try to figure out what is the range of compliance that is achievable for this
bellow structure and what they found is that the stiffness is pretty predictable
and it's in this case there's a very nice linear relationship between the stiffness of the structure and
the angle of the fold so we can take these ideas then and we can
use these modules in particular designs where we want to get a desired compliance
um and we can choose the particular parameter associated with whatever stuff compliance that we want right
now as a side note what i'm showing you here is a folded structure
and you might be wondering a question that i get a lot which is you know if you deform this thing over and over
again isn't it going to tear and break um so
my student also got very invested in this question um and put this
the bellows that you see on the left in through a cyclic test over thousands of cycles and
what you're seeing here is a typical curve for an origami structure which is that the
first cycle is very different from all of the others
but the structure very quickly converges to some sort of steady state cycle which is inconsistent over all of the
following trials and so even though these these devices are folded we can
use them over many many cycles and they serve quite a long time and the reason for this is because
actually the facial deformations that are happening inside of the structure are relatively small so the material
doesn't actually have to stretch that much and it doesn't tear so
going back to the module though what we can do now is design some sort
of robot right where if we have some particular desire stiffness in mind we can now design the
the compliant part to match that stiffness what you're seeing here
is an example of a robot where we actually did that this is a jumping robot where
the top is two and a half kilograms of just motors and the controller
and power and all of that stuff which is basically the payload of the robot
and using what we know about this payload we can tune or we can figure out what is the
necessary stiffness of the legs on the bottom that are being used to get this robot um to jump um and we
can we can basically design these springs to to to give us that stiffness
and the important what you're seeing here then is that design jumping forward consistently with a very simple rubber
style controller and the thing i want to emphasize is that one the
the design was created out of this parametrized module
and two that the springs that are being used to carry all of this load are actually quite light it's only 50 grams
of folded material not only that but because um the
the structures are compliant then that same design can actually locomote over
a wide variety of terrain so here you're seeing that exact same
design with the same controller hopping over this obstacle course of the student setup and of course the speed at which
it moves is going to change depending depending on the particular environment but it is still able to achieve this
this hopping behavior
so um one place where we're trying to take uh this project then in the future is
thinking more about well how do we then integrate um
or how do we then take advantage of the fact that we're using origami inspired fabrication here
and just as a side note one of the um
sorry one of the places that my group
is very interested in taking advantage of these structures is so that we can directly integrate all of the actuators

basically taking your circuit transferring it onto a sheet of plastic film which is then

if you also put a layer of smart material sheet in the middle you can also get these structures to self-fold

can be changed in order to get in this case in different jump heights
so basically then we have these modules of compliance structures that have

arguably the easier design design problem and the question we've been thinking

that design right so the problem looks like this
we're representing our manipulators with a dh specification and each of the

so the main insight that we've had in this section is
well yes you can automatically convert an automatic a dh
parameterization a dh specification of a manipulator directly into an origami
structure because your dh representation dictates the locations of all of your joints
but only up to a translation and so we can take advantage of this extra degree of design freedom in order
to design the particular robot we're trying to create so our main result here is that
given this set of modules that can give you rotation translation
both as a free degree of freedom or just as a rigid transformation
and the fact that all of these modules are parameterized so we can get a particular range of motion after each of

we can always construct a tubular crease pattern that
corresponds to a desired gauge specification and this is
and we have a provably correct algorithm that will allow you to do this not only that but because the compliance
can be specified then you can also add that into your specification
and the reason we can do this is because of our main insight at the top
but also what we found was that if we drill down into the specifics of the problem definition
you can actually map this problem to a dubin's path planning problem where there's been a lot of work in
computational geometry so we can basically take all of the work that people have done in
3d duven's path planning and apply them to this manipulator design problem
so what does that look like well if you're interested you can download the code and try it yourself but i'll also walk you through what the
algorithm looks like basically if i have these joints that i want to connect together
then essentially what i'm doing is i'm taking the end of one joint and trying to connect it to the
beginning of another joint and those are two joints that are on this kinematic chain right that's forming my manipulator
and if i want to connect these two joints together then i can construct
a duban's path between them right this path has both circular arcs and
trans and linear components and each of those sections can be uh converted into
a fold pattern so what that means is that if i have a joint that i want to connect to this
side and a joint i want to connect to that side i can always connect them with an origami pattern so long as i can
construct this difference path and results from computational geometry tell us that this path always exists so
long as the joints are more than a certain distance apart right and so what i can do now is i can take
my desired manipulator design and i can figure out
well where are the joint locations that allow me to get this distance apart and allow me to construct these links
between them but still maintain the desired degrees of freedom according to
my day specification so what you're seeing here is that process where for each joint i can move
it along its axis of motion without changing the actual degree of freedom that that joint provides right and i can
move it until it's more than the the desired distance away from the previous joint and i can do this in
sequence this allows me then to construct these duvets paths between the joints and to construct this this
origami pattern and the mid the resulting design here is exactly
uh corresponding to the dh specification that was provided
at the beginning right so once i have this pattern i can fold it and what you're seeing here now is the
origami pattern corresponding to the desired compliant kinematic chain
now this is not a chain that you would probably ever want to use in a robot because it's extremely complicated and
larger than it needs to be but i think what's really nice about this is that now we have provable
guarantees that any kinematic chain you want to produce is possible right
so as an illustration we took the puma arm right this is a

if we drop some of the constraints that are needed
